docs.lead_paragraph: THE self-service elevator at the Chelsea Hotel is notoriously slow. One waits and waits for its arrival, or indeed, its departure for the upper reaches of the age-old, memory-laden floors. In years past, it has creakily transported the likes of Dylan Thomas, Brendan Behan, Arthur Miller, Carl Ruggles -- and Virgil Thomson, perhaps the Chelsea's most illustrious tenant, who has lived in this most bohemian of all New York hotels for over 30 years.

headline.main: Virgil Sings of 'Lord Byron'; Virgil Sings of 'Byron'

docs.abstract: composer V Thomson int on career by J Gruen on occasion of premiere of his opera Lord Byron by Juilliard School; illus in montage with opera cast
